pm.test("Request is redirected by middleware", function () {

pm.test("'User-Agent' header is set by middleware", function () {

request.description:
Calls the `JavaScript Middleware API`, which executes two JavaScript middleware functions at the `pre` and `post` hooks.

The `pre` function does the following:
- Writes to the API Gateway application log
- Adds `User-Agent` header
- Deletes `Deleted` header
- Adds `added` URL parameter
- Deletes `deleted` URL parameter
- Changes the request body - see `data` property of response object
- Changes the requested URL - see `url` property of response object

The `post` function does the following:
- Writes to the API Gateway application log
- Adds `config-data` header using value taken from API definition `config data`
- Makes a separate HTTP request and writes the resulting response code and body to the API Gateway application log

exec: pm.test("Python middleware pre hook header is present", function () {
pm.test("Python middleware post hook header is present", function () {
pm.test("Python middleware response hook header is present", function () {

request.description:
This request calls the Python Middleware API, which uses Python to inject a custom header into the request as it is processed by the Gateway.

This middleware is configured to be activated at the `pre`, `post` and `response` hooks.

The request goes the `/get` endpoint. The server adds the headers it received into the response body - the custom headers are shown as `"Python-Plugin-Pre-Hook": "Pre Hook"` and `"Python-Plugin-Post-Hook": "Post Hook"`.

The plugin response hook adds a custom header to the response, called `Python-Plugin-Response-Hook`. It also logs the response status code to the Gateway application log. Check the Gateway's application log for entries prefixed with `Python plugin:`.

The plugin is bundled using the Gateway CLI, which outputs a signed compressed archive. This signature is then verified by the Gateway when it loads the Python plugin.

exec: pm.test("Hello World header is present", function () {

request.description:
This request calls the Go Plugin API, which uses Go to inject a custom header into the request as it is processed by the Gateway.

This API is configured to activate the plugin at the `post` hook.

The request goes the `/get` endpoint, where the server adds the headers it received into the response body - the custom header is shown as `"Hello": "World"`.

The plugin is built during the Tyk Demo bootstrap, which uses a special container to build the Go shared object (`.so`) library file, using the same Go version as that used to build the Gateway. This shared library can then be loaded by the Gateway at runtime, and the `AddHelloWorldHeader` function executed.

exec: pm.test("JWT policy id 1234 is in response", function () {

request.description:
This request uses a Go plugin to take the JWT provided in the `authorization` header, parse it, extract the value of the `pol` payload property then add the value to the request as a header.

The value can be see in the `headers.X-Jwt-Policy-Id` JSON property of the response body.

The API itself doesn't use authentication or process the JWT in any other way. It's purely an example of using a Go plugin.

exec: pm.test("Mock response data is returned", function () {

request.description:
This request uses the `Mock Response` Endpoint Designer plugin to return a response directly from the Gateway when the API endpoint is called.

The mock response lets you define the headers and body of the response, as well as the HTTP status code returned. In this example the mock response is configured as follows:
- Headers: Add a `Mock` header
- Body: Add a basic JSON object as the body
- HTTP status code: `200 OK`

When the Mock Response is executed, the request does not reach the API Server, as the Gateway provides the response directly to the API Client.

exec: pm.test("Error message is 'Requested endpoint is forbidden'", function () {

request.description: The Blacklist plugin blocks requests, returning a `403 Forbidden` response.

exec: // Before we can test this properly, we must trigger the circuit breaker so that the actual test can start from a consistent position.
// So we call the API until we get a 503, which should be a maximum of 5 attempts, at which point we wait for the service to come back online and then perform the test.
pm.test("5th server error response triggers circuit breaker", function () {
// first 4 tests should be 500s, which triggers the circuit breaker so the fifth test is 503.

request.description:
The Circuit Breaker can protect API servers by blocking requests for endpoints which are consistently returning errors.

The plugin monitors the responses from the API server for errors. If the API server returns over a certain number of errors over a particular number of requests then the API Gateway will stop proxing requests to it for a number of seconds. When the circuit breaker is activated, the API Gateway returns a `503 Service Unavailable` response.

In this example, the endpoint called by this request always returns `500 Server Error` responses, so will easily trigger the circuit breaker. The circuit breaker has been set up to sample 4 requests, and if over 50% of them result in errors then the circuit breaker will be active for 15 seconds.

exec: pm.test("Body data transformed to JSON", function () {

request.description:
The Body Transform plugin can transform data in XML and JSON formats using templates. The output format can be anything, it depends entirely on the template. Transforms can be applied to both requests and responses.

This example applies a transform on the request, changing it from XML to JSON. You can see the request body is an XML document, but the response shows that the API server receive the data as JSON - you can verify this by checking the `data` and `json` properties of the response body.

request.description:
The Enforced Timeout plugin will return an error response from the Gateway if the API server does not respond within a set time. 

This request calls the `/delay/6` endpoint, which has a 6 second delay before responding. The endpoint uses the Enforced Timeout plugin, which is configured for 4 seconds, so will repsond with a `504 Gateway Timeout` before the API server can provide a response.

exec: // pm.test("Response time is more than 1 second", function () {

request.description: This endpoint has the same configuration at part 1, but because this endpoint only has a 1 second delay, it responds in time, so the API client receives the API server response and the Enforced Timeout is not activated.

The URL Rewrite plugin can rewrite the URL based on many different parameters. This example shows the most basic version, using the default rewrite, which is used if none of the advanced rewrite rules are triggered. In this case, it rewrites to `/anything/default-rewrite` - check the `url` property in the response body to see the URL which was called on the API server.

The advanced rewriter can perform rewriting based on many aspects of a request:

- URL query
- Header
- Path
- Body
- Session metadata
- Context data

See the other parts of the URL Rewrite example for examples of the advanced URL rewriting rules.

This example triggers an advanced URL rewrite rule based on the URL parameter. It checks for a parameter with the key `query` and value `rewrite`. The plugin rewrites to the URL `/anything/rewrite-query`.

This example triggers an advanced URL rewrite rule based on the request headers. It checks for a header with the key `Header` and value `rewrite`. The plugin rewrites to the URL `/anything/rewrite-header`.

exec: pm.test("X-Req-Id header was injected into request", function () {

request.description:
This example shows how the looping functionality can be used to change the API Definition executed by the API Gateway.

Looping requests use the `tyk` URL scheme to efficiently process changes in API Definition context without having to generate additional HTTP requests.

In this case, the request calls the *Plugin Demo API* endpoint `/anything/looping`, which is configured to rewrite the URL using the `tyk` scheme, the ID of the API Definition to loop to (the *Basic Open API*) and the path `get`: `tyk://727dad853a8a45f64ab981154d1ffdad/get`.

We can verify the looping effect by checking the response body received:
- `url` shows `http://httpbin/get` which is the target host of the *Basic Open API* combined with the path from the URL rewrite rule.
- `headers.X-Req-Id` is a value injected by the *Basic Open API*.

This example uses URL Rewrite rules and Looping to redirect the request.

The API Definition which initially services this request is configured to extract the path elements, using the first (`v1`) as the version, the second (`ccc9acdb5b8646f66b2322c337d04f21`) as the api id to loop to, then the remaining path elements (`get`) as the upstream path.

The rewrite matching pattern `/(.*)/(.*)/(.*)` is rewritten as `tyk://$2/$1/$3`.

item.name: Plugin - URL Rewrite (part 6 - looping with cookies and context variables - fallback)

request.description:
This example uses URL Rewrite, Context Variables and Looping to redirect the request. It shows how the value of a cookie can be used to determine the target URL of a request.

The API Definition which initially services this request (`Cookie Redirect`) is set up to use the URL Rewrite plugin to capture all requests. The plugin is configured to use Context Variables to inspect the value of the `redirect_to` cookie:

*   By default, it redirects to `/anything/fallback-redirect` (this request)
*   If the `redirect-to` cookie value is `target-1` then it using Looping to invoke the to the `Cookie Redirect Target 1` API, which targets `http://httpbin/anything/redirect-target-1/` (a different host could be used, if desired), and append the originally requested path to the end of the redirect using the `$1` capture group.
*   If the `redirect-to` cookie value is `target-2` then it is the same process as `target-1` but to the `Cookie Redirect Target 2` API, which targets `http://httpbin/anything/redirect-target-2/`.

Check the responses received, the `url` property of the response shows the target URL used. In this case it's `http://httpbin/anything/fallback-redirect`, but for parts 7 and 8 it will be the target host of the Looped API plus the originally requested path.

item.name: Plugin - URL Rewrite (part 7 - looping with cookies and context variables - redirect 1)

exec: pm.test("Redirect-Target header was injected into request with value of 1", function () {

request.description:
This request follows on from part 6. See that example for a more detailed explanation of what is happening.

This request adds the `redirect_to` cookie to the request, with the value `target-1`. This causes the Gateway to invoke the `Cookie Redirect Target 1` API, which targets `http://httpbin/anything/redirect-target-1/` and injects a `Redirect-Target` header with the value `1`.

These actions can be seen in the body data of the response.

item.name: Plugin - URL Rewrite (part 8 - looping with cookies and context variables - redirect 2)

exec: pm.test("Redirect-Target header was injected into request with value of 2", function () {

request.description:
This request follows on from part 6. See that example for a more detailed explanation of what is happening.

This request adds the `redirect_to` cookie to the request, with the value `target-2`. This causes the Gateway to invoke the `Cookie Redirect Target 2` API, which targets `http://httpbin/anything/redirect-target-2/` and injects a `Redirect-Target` header with the value `2`.

These actions can be seen in the body data of the response.

This plugin can add and remove headers. In this example is adds a header called `New-Header` with the value `new-header-value`, and removes a header called `Delete-Header` which is sent in the request.

exec: pm.test("Response is same across two requests", function() {
pm.test("Cached response contains 'X-Tyk-Cached-Response' header set to '1'", function() {

request.description:
This request uses the `Cache` Endpoint Designer plugin to return a cached response directly from the Gateway when the API endpoint is called.

- Global Cache is enabled
- Response from Upstream will be cached for 5 seconds


When this API executed, the response from upstream API server will be cached and served for upto 5 seconds to the subsequest requests made to same Endpoint. If the Gateway returns a cached response then it will also return a header `X-Tyk-Cached-Response` in the response with the value of `1`.

This plugin is defined in the Endpoint Designer of the API Definition. It is set to execute on requests for the `Default` version of the API only.

exec: // use a unique value in the path to create a new cache, so it doesn't interfere with postman-generated request
pm.test("Cached endpoint results in faster response", function () {
// upstream endpoint has 3 second delay, so should be above 3 seconds for the first request
// response should not have cache header
// second request is within rate limit
// this request should be dealt with by cache, so should be (much) less than 3 seconds

request.description:
This example uses the cache plugin to cache a slow endpoint, to provide a faster response.

It calls an endpoint which has a 3 second delay in responding, simulating a slow response. With caching enabled at the Gateway, the Gateway will cache the response so that subsequent requests which occur within the cache lifetime are served quickly, without the need to request another response from the slow endpoint.

In this case, the API cache configuration is set to 5 seconds, so the first request will take over 3 seconds to return, as it is fetched from the slow endpoint, but requests made during the following 5 seconds will be served from the cache, resulting in a much faster response. Try clicking the send button several times to see this in action.

This request uses the **Ignore** Endpoint Designer plugin to access a protected API without providing any credentials. This API is configured to require the Client to authenticate using a token, with only the `/anything/ignored` path using the **Ignore** plugin. All other paths require authentication - see part 2.

The **Ignore** plugin instructs the Gateway to ignore the authentication settings defined in the API Definition. This allows API Clients to access ignored endpoints without providing any credentials. By default the plugin is case-sensitive, but can be configured to be case-insensitive when matching the path.

This plugin is useful in scenarios where there is a particular endpoint on the API Server that you would like to provide unauthenticated access to while keeping other endpoints protected. An authentication endpoint is a good example, where the Gateway will allow unauthenticated Clients to authenticate via the ignored endpoint, but require authentication for all other endpoints.

This part of the **Ignore** Endpoint Designer plugin example shows that endpoints of this protected API cannot be accessed by authenticated clients.

The requested path `/anything/not-ignored` has no entry in the Endpoint Designer, so generates a `401 Unauthorized` response to unauthenticated clients.

exec: pm.test("Error message is 'firstName: firstName is required'", function () {

request.description: This example sends a valid payload, so is accepted and a normal response is received from the API server.

exec: pm.test("Error message is 'Request is too large'", function () {

request.description:
The Request Size Limit Plugin validates the size of the request body against defined maximum size in byte.

In this example, the plugin is configured to only allow requests with a maximum payload size of 9 bytes. The request sends a body with 10 bytes, so is rejected with a `400 Bad Request` response.
This example succeeds because the request is 9 bytes, which the same as the configured maximum value in the plugin.

exec: pm.test("Request method is changed to POST", function () {

request.description: The Method Transform plugin changes the HTTP method used in the request. In this example, it changes the PUT method to a POST. Check the `method` property in the response body to see the method used.

The Track Endpoint plugin will record analytics about the number of times this individual endpoint has been requested. The analytics for this are visible in the Endpoint Popularity report in the Dashboard.

exec: pm.test("'Global-Add' header added to request", function () {

request.description:
The Global Version Settings plugin are applied to all endpoints for the version of the API. This plugin allows you to delete and add headers to the request. 

For this example, the plugin will delete the header `global-delete` and will add a header `global-add` with the value `global-value`. Check the response body and you will see the added header, but not the deleted header in the `headers` array.

This plugin has been configured for the `default` version of the Plugin Demo API, so you will it taking effect on any request using this API version.

exec: pm.test("Content-Type is present and set to 'text/plain; charset=utf-8'", function () {
pm.test("Response body is 'Virtual endpoint response body'", function () {

request.description:
The Virtual Endpoint plugin executes JavaScript to generate a response. The JavaScript is defined in the plugin or provided in a file. The JavaScript has access to special Tyk helper functions which make performing certain tasks easy:

- Generating a response
- Writing to the application log
- Making an HTTP request

The JavaScript is executed by a JavaScript virtual machine which runs within the Gateway. When the plugin is run it provide access to the request data, session data and API configuration data. The plugin can also make requests out to other services, allowing for orchestration across multiple upstream API servers.

In this example, the plugin simply returns a basic plain text response with a `200 OK` status code.

The Whitelist plugin causes the API Gateway to reject requests for any endpoints which are not explictly whitelisted. 

For this example a separate version of the Plugin Demo API has been created, called `whitelist`, and it has a single endpoint defined `/anything/whitelist$`. The `$` at the end of the string is the regular expression character for 'end of the string', which if not used would mean that any paths which start `/anything/whitelist` i.e. `/anything/whitelist-123` would also be accepted.

exec: pm.test("Error message is 'Requested endpoint is forbidden'", function () {

request.description: This request is rejected as the requested path `/anything/whitelist-123` has not been defined with the Whitelist plugin. The API Gateway responds with a `403 Forbidden` response.

This request uses the `Mock Response` Endpoint Designer plugin to demonstrate versioning. It shows how the API Gateway can change behaviour based on the requested version of an API. Using API versioning allows you to redefine how the API Gateway will handle endpoint requests.

The API used here has two versions:
- `Default`: the default version, used in this request, which returns a mock response directly from the Gateway
- `2`: the second version, used in part 2, which returns a response from the API server

Both versions make a request to the same API and API endpoint. The versioning is controlled by the `x-api-version` header in the request, which the Gateway will check to decide how the handle the request.

exec: pm.test("Mock response body not returned", function () {
pm.test("Version 2 of the API was requested", function () {

request.description:
Part 2 of the versioning example. This request shows that when version `2` of the API is requested, the API Gateway proxies the request to the API server.

This request uses the same URL as part 1, but uses `2` as the value for the `x-api-version` request header.

exec: pm.test("Error message is 'Api Version has expired, please check documentation or contact administrator'", function () {
pm.expect(jsonData.error).to.eql("Api Version has expired, please check documentation or contact administrator");

request.description: This request shows that version can be expired. In this case a version called `expired` was created with an expiry date in the past. This means that requests for this version are rejected by the Gateway, with a message provided in the response body which says the version has expired.

This request shows versioning using the request path. In this situation, the API version is extracted from the first path element after the listen path.

In this example the listen path is `version-by-path`, so the version is the following element `v2`. This version of the API injects a `Version` header with the value `v2`, which can be seen in the body of the response returned from the server.

exec: // Add test to check if webhook fired

request.description:
This example makes an unauthenticated request to the `Basic Protected API`. The API requires authentication so the request fails, as expected, with a `403 Forbidden` response.

The `Basic Protected API` is configured to use a webhook in the event of authentication failure. This webhook calls another API, passing information about the failed request. You can see this webhook call in the Dashboard analytics, it's made to the `Webhook Receiver` API, and will appear straight after this failed API request to `Basic Protected API`. In the analytics record, check the body of the request to see origin of the request and key which was used.

Webhooks can be set up to handle lots of different types of events, such as rate limit exceeded, quota exceeded etc. They can also be configured with a cooldown time so that the events don't overload the API receiving the webhooks.

exec: pm.test("'X-Req-Id' header is a UUID", function () {

request.description:
Header `X-Req-Id` is injected by the Gateway, and can be seen in the response body. 

The header value is a GUID representing the random id assigned to each request by the Gateway. It is configured using the Tyk context variable `$tyk_context.request_id`.

The value is accessible to various parts of the Tyk middleware chain, so can be used as a reference when processing requests.

exec: pm.test("Status code is 200 for tyk-gateway-2", function () {
pm.test("Status code is 200 for tyk-gateway", function () {

request.description:
This request demonstrates the segmentation feature. It calls the **Basic Open API**, which has the `tyk-gateway-2` segment tag applied to it. 

This means that the API will only be loaded by Gateways which are configured to use tags and also have the same tag (i.e. `tyk-gateway-2`). Gateways which have `node_is_segmented` set to `false` in `tyk.conf` (i.e. `tyk-gateway`) will load all API Definitions regardless of their tags.

See part 2 for an example of an API which is not available on both Gateways.

exec: pm.test("Status code is 404 for tyk-gateway-2", function () {
pm.test("Status code is 200 for tyk-gateway", function () {

request.description:
This request shows that `tyk-gateway-2` is not able to proxy requests for the **Basic Protected API**. 

A `404 Not Found` response is returned when this API is requested. This is because the API does not have any segmentation tags applied, and `tyk-gateway-2` has the segmentation tag `tyk-gateway-2`, which means that it will only load API Definitions which also have this tag. 

**Basic Protected API** is available through `tyk-gateway`, as it does not have segmentation enabled. This is demonstrated in the test.

exec: pm.test("Error message is 'Authorization field missing'", function () {

request.description:
This API will showcase the Token authorization feature of Tyk.

An key is not provided in the HTTP header field `Authorization`, resulting in am HTTP status code `401 Unauthorized` returned by the Gateway.

exec: pm.test("Error message is 'Access to this API has been disallowed'", function () {
pm.expect(jsonData.error).to.eql("Access to this API has been disallowed");

request.description:
This request attempts to authenticate with a key which does not exist - `missing_key`.

This results in am HTTP status code `403 Forbidden` response from the Gateway.

This API showcases the Token authorization feature of Tyk.

The key is sent in the HTTP header field `Authorization`. It has been authorized access to the `Basic Protected API`, so the request is accepted by the Gateway.

This request uses JWT authentication using a shared HMAC secret. In this case, the secret is defined on the API definition, but it is also possible to define it separately, which allows multiple secrets to be used.

The JWT claims are processed as follows:

* `sub`: This is the subject, and is used by Tyk as the identity of the API Client. Tyk creates a session based on the value provided here, which allows it to maintain state for the subject across multiple requests.
* `pol`: This is the Id of the Policy to use, if the request is authenticated. If no Id is provided then the API Definition specifies a default Policy to use.

For reference, the payload of the JWT:

```json
{
  "sub": "1234567890",
  "pol": "5ead72955759610001818688"
}
```

item.name: JWT - shared HMAC secret with claim (part 1)

request.description:
This request uses a claim in the JWT to define the Policy to use. In this case, the API Definition is configured to inspect the `policy_claim` claim and match the value (`restricted`) against the list defined in the API Definition. 

In this case, the claim matches against the `JWT Policy Restricted` Policy, which uses path-based permissions to only allow requests for `GET /anything/allowed-path`. Requests for other endpoints will be rejected - see part 2.

For reference, the payload of the JWT:

```json
{
  "sub": "1234567890",
  "policy_claim": "restricted"
}
```

item.name: JWT - shared HMAC secret with claim (part 2)

pm.expect(jsonData.error).to.eql("Access to this resource has been disallowed");

request.description: This request fails because it attempts to access an endpoint which is not listed in the path-based permissions defined in the Policy. The Gateway responds with a `403 Forbidden`.

This request uses basic authentication to access the Basic Authentication API. Basic authenticate is based on a username and password.

The request has an `Authorization` header which has a value comprised of a prefix `Basic` and a base64 encoded representation of the credentials. The value used is the username and password separated with a colon. In this case the username is `basic-auth-username` and the password is `basic-auth-password`, so this gives `basic-auth-username:basic-auth-password`, which is `YmFzaWMtYXV0aC11c2VybmFtZTpiYXNpYy1hdXRoLXBhc3N3b3Jk` when base64 encoded.

request.description:
This request calls an API which is configured to use a Go plugin to perform authentication.

The plugin source is located at `/deployments/tyk/volumes/tyk-gateway/plugins/go/example/example-go-plugin.go`, and the resulting shared object file is referenced from the `auth_check` hook in the API Definition.

The functionality roughly follows the standard token auth processes. The key is analysed and loaded from the Redis storage. The access is authorised and a session object is created.

The plugin writes many entries to the application log, to show how it is processing the request.

This request retrieves an OAuth client. The client is added to the system as part of the bootstrap process, and is associated with the "OAuth 2.0 API" API Definition and its corresponding Policy "OAuth 2.0 Policy".

The client's id and secret can be used to generate an API token for the "OAuth 2.0 API".

item.name: OAuth - Generate API Token Using Client Credentials

exec: pm.test("Token can access OAuth 2.0 API", function () {

request.description:
This request uses an OAuth client to generate a token which can be used to access an API protected with OAuth 2.0.

The request `authorization` header uses basic-style authentication credentials, using a base64 encoded string of the OAuth client id and secret.

The request body contains the grant type and the OAuth client id and secret.

The response body provides the bearer token, which can then be used to access the API. The token has a expiry, which defaults to 3600 seconds (1 hour), after which the token is no longer valid for authentication.

request.description:
This API will showcase the Rate limiting feature of Tyk.

Rate limit is set as 2 per 5 seconds. More than 2 request per 5 will result in `429  Too many requests` error from gateway.

This API will showcase the Throttling feature of Tyk.

Rate limit is set as 2 per 5 seconds. Gateway Throttling is configured for 10 times with 1 sec interval. 

We can obeserve a delay in response due to throttling after the rate limit has been reached.

This API will showcase the Quota limiting feature of Tyk.

Quota limit is set as 2 per hour. More than 2 request per hour will result in `403 Forbidden` error from gateway.

exec: pm.test("Consecutive requests go to different hosts", function () {

request.description:
This request calls an API Definition which is configured to load balance the proxied requests across multiple upstream hosts. The API Definition specifies two hosts, `httpbin` and `httpbin2`. The Gateway uses round-robin load balancing, so each host is called in turn.

Check the `headers.Host` property of the response body, it will alternative between `httpbin` and `httpbin2`. This shows that the Gateway is load balancing the upstream requests.

exec: // if response is not 404, then the API is active and should be tested, otherwise skip tests

request.description:
**Note:** The API for this request must be activated before running the request. The API is inactive by default to prevent failing uptime tests from repeatedly generating error messages in the application logs. To activate the API, log in to the Dashboard, edit the 'Uptime Test API', set `active` to `true` (you can click the 'API Inactive' button) then update the API.

***

This request calls an API which uses Uptime Tests to monitor the health of the upstream hosts it is configured to proxy requests to.

In this case, it is configred load balance requests upstream to `httpbin` and `httpbin2`. An uptime test has been added to the API Definition which calls the `status/500` endpoint of the `httpbin` host. This endpoint always returns `HTTP 500` status codes, which causes the uptime test to fail, triggering the removal of the `httpbin` host from the load balancer. This means that requests sent to this API will only be proxied to the `httpbin2` host, since the `httpbin` host has been marked as unhealthy.

Check the `headers.Hosts` property of the response body. This will always show `httpbin2`.

In order for the Gateway to remove the unhealthy host from the load balancer, the API Definition must have both nn Uptime Test using the same hostname, and the `check_host_against_uptime_tests` property set to `true`. If `check_host_against_uptime_tests` is not set to `true` then the unhealthy host will not be removed from the load balancer, only an event will be raised.

**Note**: To reduce the amount of warning messages in the Gateway application log generated by failing tests, the uptime tests have been configured to run every 30 seconds. This means that on initial startup, the Gateway will proxy to both hosts (`httpbin` and `httpbin2`) until the first Uptime Test is run.

This request is uses a custom hostname to demonstrate the **Custom Domain** functionality. This enables API Defintions to be mapped against the hostname and the path of the request. In this instance, there is an API Definition which is configured to use Custom Domain `custom-domain.localhost` and path `/`. This allows the path for the upstream API to be the only element in the request path i.e. `/get`, since the Gateway no longer has to rely on the path as the only means to identify the API being requested.

item.name: GraphQL - Proxy to external GraphQL API (part 1)

request.description:
This request demonstrates the Gateways ability to proxy GraphQL requests to a target GraphQL API. It calls the **GraphQL Countries** API, which is configured to proxy requests to an external GraphQL API https://countries.trevorblades.com/.

The body of the request is a GraphQL query, which requests a **country** object which has a **code** equal to **GB**, returning the fields **code** and **name**. The API Definition is set up to only allow these fields, even though the target API contains many additional fields.

The **Country** data returned in the response matches the code **GB**.

item.name: GraphQL - Proxy to external GraphQL API (part 2)

exec: pm.test("Contextual error message: Currency field not defined", function () {
pm.expect(jsonData.errors[0].message).to.eql("field: currency not defined on type: Country");

request.description:
Part 2 of the GraphQL requests makes a request for a field which does not exist in the *Schema* defined on the API Definition.

The **currency** field does not exist in the schema, and as such the request is rejected by the Gateway, returning an HTTP 400 response. The target API does actually have this field, but since the API Gateway does not list it in the schema it cannot be requested.

The response contains a contextual error message which identifies that the **currency** field is not defined for the type **Country**. This allows the API Client is understand why the request was rejected.

exec: pm.test("Data for user ID 1 is returned", function () {

request.description:
This GraphQL API illustrates, with a single request, the ability to combine 3 requests destined for 3 DataSources (all of which are of type REST) listed below: *
https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/users/{{.arguments.id}}
*
https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts?userId={{.object.id}}
*
https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/comments?postId={{.object.id}}
Key Concept #1 - GraphQL GraphQL is able to make calls to multiple DataSources with a single request to the following upstream endpoints: * /users * /posts * /comments Key Concept #2 - Universal Data Graph Universal Data Graph uses what are known as **arguments** which are values used in the URL by the DataSource to retreive data. In the call to the **/users** endpoint, an argument is passed to reference the ID of the user. The GraphQL engine takes the argument with the name **id** and uses it in the URL to make the request to the REST API.

exec: pm.test("Data is returned from GraphQL data source", function () {
pm.test("Data is returned from REST data source", function () {

request.description:
This request is for a composed GraphQL API. This means that the Gateway takes the request and generates the response by calling multiple upstream APIs and combining the responses together.

The **Universal Data Graph** can target APIs already defined in Tyk and also external APIs. The API Definition for the API called in this example uses **DataSources** to target two APIs. One is another GraphQL API, **GraphQL Countries**, which already exists as an API Definition. The other is a REST API which is not defined as an API Definition, and is defined as a URL which the Universal Data Graph will make a request to.

All the data is combined in to a single response. The schema in the API Definition defines how this is achieved:

- The Universal Data Graph takes the query contained in the body of the request and provides the **code** property as an **argument** to the GraphQL Countries API. It also uses the code as an argument in the request to the REST API, placing the value in the URL called by the Universal Data Graph.
- The data returned by the REST API is mapped on the API's schema by using a **field mapping**. This maps the field **population** in the REST API response to the **pop** property in the API's schema. Field mapping enables fields to be renamed to fit with the desired schema.

This request shows how [detailed analytics logging](https://tyk.io/docs/analytics-and-reporting/useful-debug-modes/#enabling-detailed-logging) can be configured at a **global** (Gateway) level. Detailed analytics data will be recorded if it is enabled at any of the three levels - global, API and key.

The Gateway host targetted by this request, `tyk-gateway.localhost`, has it's configuration `analytics_config.enable_detailed_recording` set to `false`.

This example *does not* record detailed analytics data because it:
- goes to an API Gateway that does not have detailed analytics recording enabled (**global** level), and
- calls an API Definition that does not have detailed analytics recording enabled (**API** level), and
- uses no API key, so cannot have detailed analytics recording enabled at **key** level

This request shows how [detailed analytics logging](https://tyk.io/docs/analytics-and-reporting/useful-debug-modes/#enabling-detailed-logging) can be configured at a **global** (Gateway) level. Detailed analytics data will be recorded if it is enabled at any of the three levels - global, API and key.

The Gateway host targetted by this request, `tyk-gateway-2.localhost`, has it's configuration `analytics_config.enable_detailed_recording` set to `true`.

This example *does* record detailed analytics data because it:
- goes to an API Gateway that has detailed analytics recording enabled (**global** level)

The API targetted by this request, `detailed-analytics-off`, has it's configuration `enable_detailed_recording` set to `false`.

This example *does not* record detailed analytics data because it:
- goes to an API Gateway that does not have detailed analytics recording enabled (**global** level), and
- calls an API Definition that does not have detailed analytics recording enabled (**API** level), and
- uses no API key, so cannot have detailed analytics recording enabled at **key** level

This request shows how [detailed analytics logging](https://tyk.io/docs/analytics-and-reporting/useful-debug-modes/#enabling-detailed-logging) can be configured at an **API** level. Detailed analytics data will be recorded if it is enabled at any of the three levels - global, API and key.

The API targetted by this request, `detailed-analytics-on`, has it's configuration `enable_detailed_recording` set to `true`.

This example *does* record detailed analytics data because it:

- calls an API Definition that has detailed analytics recording enabled (**API** level)

This request shows how [detailed analytics logging](https://tyk.io/docs/analytics-and-reporting/useful-debug-modes/#enabling-detailed-logging) can be configured at a **Key** level. Detailed analytics data will be recorded if it is enabled at any of the three levels - global, API and key.

The Key used by this request, `auth_key`, has it's configuration `enable_detailed_recording` set to `false`.

This example *does* record detailed analytics data because it:

exec: pm.test("Response key is not empty", function () {

request.description:
This request uses the Gateway API to import a custom key. The Gateway API is used as the Gateway is responsible for managing keys.

The URL defines the id that the key will be assigned, in this instance `my-custom-key`, which is very different to the random values assigned by the Gateway when creating keys normally.

Once imported, the key can be used to access the `Basic Protected API` (see part 2), as defined in the `access_rights` section of the key definition JSON (see request Body).

This request uses the custom key imported in Part 1 (which must be run prior to this) to access a protected API.

The custom key is provided in the `Authorization` header of the request.

This request is sent to the container mapped on port `8081`. It is the TLS-enabled Gateway which is otherwise configured the same as the HTTP-only Gateway.

You can use the `add-gateway.sh` script to add more Gateways. Note that in order to access them using this request, you will need to use `http` and change the port number - the Gateway created by the script has a random port assigned to it.

This request calls the Gateway's health check endpoint. The default endpoint for this is `/hello`, but this can be altered by setting the `health_check_endpoint_name` value in the Gateway's configuration file `tyk.conf`.

The health check endpoint can be used by network components, such as load balancers, to avoid sending traffic to unhealthy instances.

The endpoint implements the [Heath Check Response Format](https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-inadarei-api-health-check-01.html) defined by the IETF. This provides information about both the Gateway's health and the health of the Gateway's dependencies. The dependencies are Redis and, depending on configuration, the Tyk Dashboard or Multi Data Centre Bridge.

The `status` property returned in the response body can have the following values:
- `pass`: healthy
- `fail`: unhealthy
- `warn`: healthy, with some concerns

In this scenario, the `status` returned in the body should be `pass`, as the Gateway and it's dependancies, `dashboard` and `redis`, should not be experiencing any problems.

item.name: Basic Test Request for Acme Organisation

exec: pm.test("Acme organisation header is present", function () {

request.description:
This request makes a request for a basic API set up in the Acme Organisation. This is to demonstrate that Tyk can handle multiple tenants in a single deployment. The response contains a custom header `Organisation: Acme` which is injected by the Gateway for the API definition managed by the Acme Organisation.

When a tenant logs into the Dashboard, they can only access and manage data within their own Organisation.

APIs from mulitple Organisations can be deployed to the same set of Gateways. Alternatively, API tagging or MDCB deployments can be used to segregate APIs onto separate Gateways.

exec: pm.test("Message confirms SSO Nonce created", function () {

request.description:
This request calls the Dashboard Admin API SSO endpoint to generate a one-time use login token.

The request body specifies the context in which the login token can be used:
- `ForSection`: Either `dashboard` or `portal`
- `OrgId`: Defines the Organisation context for the session
- `EmailAddress`: If provided, will lookup the email address and log in the session as that user
- `GroupId`: If provided, will lookup the user group and assign it to the session

If the request is successful, the response will have a `200 OK` status and the body will contain a property called `Meta`, the value of which is the login token. This token can then be used to call the SSO endpoint of the Dashboard or Portal to generate the session and log into the application.

The Standard Dashboard API can also be used for SSO, as it has an equivilant SSO endpoint `/api/sso`, which requires authentication using a Dashboard User's API access token via the `authorization` header.

### Using the login token

Create the SSO login URL by combining the SSO endpoint URL (http://tyk-dashboard.localhost:3000/tap?nonce=) with the login token value (`Meta` property returned the response) e.g. `ZDhlNDY4ODktMzU2MC00ZmQwLTY5Y2MtZTcxYzNkNGYzYTJl`. Use the resulting URL your browser. You will then be logged into the Dashboard.

For example http://tyk-dashboard.localhost:3000/tap?nonce=ZDhlNDY4ODktMzU2MC00ZmQwLTY5Y2MtZTcxYzNkNGYzYTJl (Note, this URL will not work, it's just an example.)

This request uses the HTTPS scheme to connect to the API Gateway. The Gateway is configured to listen for requests on `tyk-gateway-2.localhost:8081` and use a locally stored self-signed certificate.

This is configured in the `http_server_options` section of the Gateway's configuration file.
**Note:** self-signed cetificates will fail verification by an API client, which will prevent the request for working. To resolve this, configure your client to allow self-signed certificates.

exec: pm.test("Error message is 'Authorization field missing'", function () {
pm.test("Response contains custom error message", function () {
pm.expect(jsonData.customErrorTemplate).to.eql("This is a custom error response template for HTTP 401 responses using JSON");

request.description:
This request demonstrates how Error Templates enable the responses returned by the Gatewey to be customised.

In this case, a 401 response is generated as no authentication is provided in the request. To generate the response, the Gateway checks the `templates` directory for a file called `error_401.json`. If the file exists, then it will use that as a template to generate the response. If not, then it will use the default `error.json` file. 

The custom template contains an addition property `customErrorTemplate` which contains a message, and also the error message generated by the Gateway. The error message is injected into the output using the Go templating syntax `{{.Message}}`.

The Gateway uses the HTTP response code and the content-type of the request to define which file it will check for. This allows for different templates to use used for different HTTP response codes. JSON and XML are the supported content types.

Error Templates do not affect responses returned from the upstream API server, only responses Generated directly from the Gateway itself.

This request gets all the Organisations. These are the root objects in the Dashboard database, which other objects are linked to.

Organistaions enable multi-tenancy in the Tyk Dashboard.

This request calls the special `/tyk/batch` endpoint, which enables the Gateway to make multiple API requests baesd on a single API request received from the client. The special batch endpoint path is added to the listen path for the API, and must end with a trailing slash.

When calling the batch endpoint, the API client must specify the requests that the Gateway will make. In this case, the body defines two requests which go to `/uuid` and `/get`. The request for `/get` also adds a custom header with the key `batch-request`. 

The `suppress_parallel_execution` property defines whether the Gateway will send the requests sequentially or in parallel - in this case the setting is `true`, so the Gateway will send the requests in in sequence, which means the response data will be in the same sequence.

The response body contains data about the responses the Gateway received for the requests. The `requests` property contains the response data, showing the URL called, HTTP status, headers and body data received.

The batch request functionality must be enabled on the API definition by setting `enable_batch_request_support` to `true`.

exec: pm.test("Body status value is ok", function () {

request.description:
This request forces the Gateways to reload their API and Policies from the Dashboard. During this process the Gateway can continue serving requests.

The reload is automatically handled when using the Dashboard to manage APIs and Policies. But this functionality can be useful for CI/CD or when the Gateway is not managed by the Dashboard.

exec: // this test relies on the "/plugin-demo-api/uuid" endpoint using the cache plugin
pm.test("Body message value is 'cache invalidated'", function () {
pm.test("Response differs after cache is cleared", function() {
// check that response 1 and 2 are the same - i.e. the caching works
// check that the responses 2 and 3 are different - i.e. the cache invalidation works

request.description:
This request calls the cache invalidation Gateway API endpoint, which invalidates the cached responses for an API which have been stored by the Gateway. 

This is done on a per-API basis, with the API id provided as the last part of the URL path - in this case `4692b70056154ccb41e44af0cdd990c3`. This clears any cached responses the Gateway has stored for the API. If successful, the API client will receive a response with a `200 OK` HTTP status, and a body message stating `cache invalidated`.

The cached data will be removed from Redis, so will affect any other Gateways which are using the same Redis instance.

The process of cache invalidation can also be initiated through the Dashboard API.

exec: // this also essentially tests that the listen path is working

request.description:
This request calls the **Secret API**, which has its *listen path* and *target URL* set using secret values taken from the Gateway's configuration file. It also injects a header called `Secret-Header` with the value `secret-header-value`.

The values are stored in a key/value array called `secrets` in the Gateway's configuration file `tyk.conf`:
```
  "secrets": {
    "target_url": "http://httpbin/",
    "listen_path": "/secret-path/"
    "header": "secret-header-value"
  }
```

These values can be used as values in the API Definition.
- When setting the *listen path* and *target URL*, the syntax is `secrets://value` where `value` is the key for the `secrets` array e.g. `secrets://target_url`. 
- When used in other contexts, such as setting a header value, the syntax is `$secret_conf.value` e.g. `$secret_conf.header`.

The Gateway can also pull key/value pairs from secret stores such as Vault and Consul. See https://tyk.io/docs/tyk-configuration-reference/kv-store/ for more information.

request.description:
This is a basic test request to check that the Gateway is working ok.
